Description: senses different person and turns on relevant lights and notifies user of intruder
wearable light that gives lights and communicates with other lights with dimmers and touch tracks and a personal light
voice control option but added integrated touch light system
Simple remote with big buttons that can access and deal with many room controls similar to hospitals
wearable self controllable portable light that is sleek and easy to keep like a sleeve for specific use where need be
a small portable palette of switches that can control different things and is wireless
a small wireless controller with sets of spinning time tickers that correspond to different controls that work like kitchen timers to turn things on
A simple servo motor attached to an arm that throws all the switches in the house that can be simply put over them by a user
A centralized panel within the house that sense the user and turns on lights and area appliances accordingly
A smart house device that responds by turning things on when the user says exactly what he wants into a small microphone
A large scale app that can control every light light the Q app already does extended into appliances
feature that turns on relevant lights when someone without clearance is within proximity of home ie:burgular
Every light switch has sensors that can track your eyes and see what part of the room you are focusing on in order to optimally light the room
Hook up a variable speed motor to any dimmer or a capacitor that can slowly discharge in order to dim the lights over time as you go to sleep
Panel of light switches that follows you around the room
Make every room's walls have a sensor that allows you to touch a wall to light up the room and touch it to turn it off again
Tracks cell signall in house to bring light to wherever phones are in the house with users ideally being there as well
Looks at user behavior and runs lights along house like security lights and light up certain paths that you commonly take at certain times
Put an RFID scanner on your door that automatically turns off everything when you leave and turns everything back on when you come back and tap your card again
In-house moniter of energy usage and suggestions given to user for better and proper plans of use
A nerf gun bullet that has magnet on it. And attach a piece of an opposite magnet to the switch. Literally kills the switch before you go to bed
It's one of the simplest mechanism to extend the switch to where you want it. Pull down on the strings to turn off/on the switch.
One remote that controls all switches in the house. There is an add-on to the switch which will be controlled by the remote
There would be no physical light switch except a screen which tells you if the light is on/off. You can tap on the screen to turn on/off or use application
Each button corresponds to a set of light being turned on/off. So we don't have to walk around the house to switch each one on/off.
An add on timer that goes on top of your switch. The lever moves down to turn the light off when the timer is done
A switch that reduces current to no current slowly instead of killing the light when we hit the switch. This allows people to walk safely back to bed.
A motion sensor that cut and connect power to the light when something close to it moves (~8 inches)
The string will be guided on the wall to wherever you desire it to be so it doesn't block your way.
This sensor detects light. Enough current will flow to turn on light when there is no UV light detected by the light sensor and vice versa.
At a certain time range, the light will go off when someone sleeps/lays on the bed
The application and screen can also dim lights instead of just turning it on/off.
A remote that controls switches in the house. The remote is labeled and the add-on controls the switch with magnet.
Controls light/other switches by doing one click on the remote/button. Can be wired/wireless
Step on the pad on the floor to turn light on/off
Replace your light switch with this device to transmit signal so you can control it from a distance
A rail that allows the switch to be slided to a different part of your room
Connect the switch to an application that has data of sunrise/sunset everyday. Lights will be seton/off according to that automatically
Light goes off when you click on "sleep". Then it detects your sleep. Within 10 minutes before your alarm, light will turn on when it's best to wake you up.
Dial a certain number from any phone to turn switch on/off. A similar application exists in door buzzers in apartments.
Product comes with a magnet that gets placed on switch. Button is pressed and the internal magnets are wirelessly activated and flip so the magnets flip switch and charge.
Switch control same as above--actual control is a ball in a holder that rotates about one axis and dims the light up and down with just your palm.
Product is a chain with a ring that goes around the switch. Button is pressed and servo motor is activated and flips causing ring to move switch up/down.
Switch control same as above, the device is operated like a pressure plate. The mat is placed beside and triggers the switch on/off when stepped on.
Touchscreen activated and made of spring loaded arms that push the switch either from the top or bottom once activated. Arms in different location depending on switch type.
Control uses the wireless mechanism but is triggered by a big red button. Red is a vibrant color and easy to locate for those with poor sight or mental disabilities.
Control uses a smartphone app to connect to the apparatus placed on top of switch. Works on all smartphone platforms, and can control brightness if switch is for a light.
Control uses a string connected from the switch to hooks overhead to a handle over the bed--users can pull the string once in bed and turn off the light.
Control senses motion by the light switch, and senses the direction telling it whether to turn it on/off. When someone enters, it will turn the light on, and vice-versa.
This device is captures a sound recording (that can be rerecorded whenever) that will activate the flip of a switch each time that recorded statement is said again out loud.

Concept Title: Remote and Rolling Dimmer for Multiple Switches
Description: This base has an added extension to the roller where you can press which switch you'd like to dim before using the dimmer itself
Instead of having two magnets with opposite polarization that flip, one magnet would be inside that slides up or down to dim or turn on/off
Wall switches will be color coated with one big strip of colored buttons that can be placed on the wall or on an end table that remotely control the switch corresponding to the color
Instead of a button on the contraption that switches it on or off, there is a dimmer slider that can slowly move the chain to dim the light
Several Mats on the floor of a bedroom control the intensity of the lights. As someone walks to bed, the lights get increasingly darker.
Not only can you control the contraction on the switch itself with a tap, we can have tap stickers that you can place anywhere that you can tap to flip the switch
The app can not only control the light switches, but be able to control different parts of the house.
One strip of lights that goes along one wall and plugs in.  As you walk by, the section where you're walking lights up.
A waterproof button sewed into two pieces of fabric.  One piece of fabric has a sticky side that can attach to a bed sheet, and one has to press it to activate the switch.
To control both a switch and an alarm system, the control can recognize vocals, but also recognize a fingerprint when it's time to lock up.
A wearable wristband light with a built in LED light that can be extended from the wristband and adjusted for specific application.
An IOS or Android application that would give users access to all controls in their living space with detailed descriptions of what each switch controls.
A GPS enabled drone that can find its way to different switches in a room and switch them on and off; it can also provide external light to its user.
A smartwatch with the sole purpose of controlling switches and appliances in a living space
A personalized control box that can control all switches in a living space and includes information about all utilities in the home to provide the user information about his/her living space.
An infrared sensor remote with a single button that can control any switch in a living space by pointing the remote at the switch.
A remote than can recognize user speech to control switches in a living space.
A pen with pressable buttons on the side that control all switches within a living space.
A sort of bar code scanner that can scan wall switches and provide information about that switch and what it controls.
A clip-on switch that can be placed directly over a wall switch that can be controlled by either a smartphone app or remote control
A drone that follows around the user wearing a GPS enabled wristband that can toggle switches to rooms that the user walks into and provides external light for the user via a build in LED
Any apparel of clothing that includes labeled room controls for user to function controls within their living space
A one-button remote that had an attachable LED that can be pointed at light switches and can toggle them on and off. Includes a laser and attachable light to tell user where it is pointing.
A one button portable switch that can shut off all of the power within a living space using electromagentic signals.
A training program designed for service dogs that will teach them how to turn switches on and off for those who cannot reach switches in the moment.
An integrated system in the home that can have timers set to turn off lights, lock doors, and set alarms at a time set by the user when the system is installed.
A camera set up in each room with shape recognition to received hand gesture signals from the user to control switches within that room.

A brail control board that allows users that have trouble seeing at some point during the day to feel the control box to know which switch they want to press to control switches without having to physically see the label.
A one button control system that controls all switches within a living space using a morse code toggled command.
A pressure plate in the entrance of each room that turns the room lights on when a user enters and turns them off when the user leaves the room
A device mounted over a switch, possibliy replacing a face plate, that allows for automation of the switch
A small magnetic attatchment to the face plate of a flat switch that has an actuated slider that allows for control of the switch
A hub that you can insert into the outlet that can remotely control the output of the outlet.
A wrist/arm strap that contains a light that can shine forward or downward to aid work in poor lighting.
A light bulb adaptor that attatches in between the bulb and socket that can remotely control the light.
A simple remote that is easily programmable to control all the remote switch, plug, and bulb adapters.
A bracelet version of the remote that is more portable and personal, that could allow for motion control of appliances and lighting.
A deadbolt lock for your door that can be remotely controlled and allows users to make sure their doors are locked while away.
A signle switch that easily allows someone to turn off all unnecessary electronics in their room from one spot when they leave, in order to save power.
A lighting system that surrounds the room and can be selectively lit to accommodate where you need light at a specific instance.
A light on a rail that goes arround the room and follows a user.
Light Bulb Adapter that has a flexible extended sensor for obstructed lights
Socket Adaptor that has a flexible extended sensor that can be remotely controlled
A key with a small mechanism that toggles when you lock your door, so you can look at the key later and see if your door is locked
Blinds that can be remotely controlled via a servo motor or actuator
A bracelet that can be worn and can recognize hand gestures that can be programmed to control different appliances and room controls

A room control device that uses heat sensing or something other than motion to sense if someone is in the room.  Motion sensing may not work because if someone is just sitting there, it may detect that everyone has left and the room is empty.
An app that lets users know how much power each room in their house is drawing in order to track energy usage
A light switch that can be physically removed from the wall and used as a remote for that specific switch.
An app that lets users in shared living spaces control room they are staying in together
